intro: Sinapis caspica, commonly known as Caspian mustard, is an annual flowering plant native to Central Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes many other mustard species. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring upright stems and alternate leaves that are lance-shaped and hairy. Its flowers are small, yellow, and arranged in racemes, while the pods are slender and contain several seeds. The plant is adapted to arid environments and is often found in dry grasslands and along roadsides.
